div.head: Title of Note
div.p: Prideauxʼs criticism of Slaterʼs Early Editions, that it ranked the significance of modern first editions too much according to their market value, appears justified. As a guide for comprehensive collecting, Slaterʼs book is eccentric. For example, in the chapter on Ruskin, Slater mentions in passing a number of “publications which for one reason or another it has been thought undesirable to describe in full,” generally because of “the unimportance of the items from the collectorʼs standpoint.” Among these, he lists the 1868 pamphlet of “Leoni,” which he notes as rare (and which he presumably did not recognize to be a forgery). Nonetheless, in the list of Ruskin publications that he does formally describe, he includes the Salsette and Elephanta pamphlet, the Poems (1850), and the Poems (1891). While Slater may have omitted the “Leoni” pamphlet merely on the grounds of having “not been able to meet with” a copy, his caveats do not explain the “unimportance,” in his view, of the other Ruskin pamphlets he omits (Slater, Early Editions, 219, 221–22, 226, 247–48, 219)..

Here, the reviewer mourns the “pathetic sight” of the child “immersed” in “days and nights” of “labours” over “its French exercises, its German exercises, its Italian exercises, its Greek exercises, its Latin exercises, its lessons in music, drawing, arithmetic, geography, and all the rest of it.” Britain, in this argument, becomes a green space, where “in every meadow and lane in England,” childhoodʼs “true and only schoolmistress, Nature,” cries out for the child to read fairy tales “under the waving trees.” Correspondingly, “infant literature” (here, literature for children, not by them) is an essentialist experience, belonging to Wordsworthʼs “literature of power”: “it is impossible to calculate how enormous in moulding the mind is the power of infant literature. It is not merely that what we read in childhood we never forget, but that it becomes part of our very being” .(“Mrs. Browningʼs Earlier Poems”, 722).

The admission appears to beg the question of his own culpability on the same grounds that he pleaded against Shepherd—that the personal wishes of “writers of eminence” and their families were being ignored. Even if Browning genuinely believed Shelleyʼs early poetry to be unworthy, his testimony gives the appearance of his having acted in bad faith compared to Shepherd, who at least professed to admire Barrett Browningʼs early poems. Despite this weakness arising in cross‐examination, Browningʼs testimony succeeded in framing the terms for the Athenaeumʼs final word on the conflict. In comments appended to a (largely favorable) review of a compilation of Waltoniana compiled by the Shepherd, the journal reacted to the juryʼs decision in Shepherdʼs favor by listing what the journal editors interpreted as Shepherdʼs self‐confessed infringements and concluded: “It will be a lasting benefit to literature when it comes to be universally recognized that no desire to ‘provide caviare for a few students’ can excuse the defiance of the wishes of a great writer with respect to his own poems or those of his wife” (Unsigned review of Waltoniana, 786). Browning also revisited an argument that the journal had conceded could not be sustained on strictly legal grounds (“were it a question of tables or chairs, Mr. Browning could defend the wishes of his wife; but in the case of poems, our wise laws give him no remedy” [“Literary Gossip”, 25 November 1876, 690]), and he ignores the journalʼs new argument—on grounds of national, rather than personal interest—that the journal pressed in its December 1877 review of the reprint (although the writer deftly clings to personal claims, alongside wider ones, by remarking that, “even if the volume of 1826 had been reprinted by the only man who has any right to reprint it—Mr. Browning—we could scarcely . . . have approved the undertaking” owing to the poemsʼ lack of merit [Unsigned review of The Earlier Poems of Elizabeth Barrett Browning, 766]). Perhaps by shifting back to claims of personal interest, Browning fatally bared himself to contradictions exposed by the prosecution.

In Shepherdʼs difficulties with modern writers and the public press, two sets of contradictions appear to be in play that bear on ERMʼs concerns with nineteenth‐century childrenʼs writing. One set of contradictions, which relates to the status of juvenilia in the editing and canonization of eminent Victorian writers, the uses of juvenilia in biography and autobiography of those writers, and the context of Collecting of Modern Authors in the Late Nineteenth and Early Twentieth Centuries, is the clash between the efforts of pioneering scholars and editors of modern literature like Shepherd to represent an authorʼs corpus genetically and comprehensively and the authority claimed by many Victorian writers to erase genetic evidence and vest legitimacy solely in a later, revised canon. On the evidence of Shepherd versus the Athenaeum, in the final third of the century this conflict was playing out in terms of national and of private interests—terms that themselves were not necessarily compatible. The second set of contradictions revolves around the figure of the precocious child. Again, in the contradiction is played out in terms of national versus private interests, with the former leading the journal to a negative view of the precocious child whose “economy of Nature” must be mechanistically managed to prove beneficial to the nation, whereas Shepherd advances a positive view of precocity with the aid of an organic, developmental metaphor of Romantic imagination in nature. A further contradiction is that the Athenaeum, even while pursuing its feud with Shepherd, could swerve to admiring and validating the authority of youthful imagination by using a paradigm that appears compatible with Shepherdʼs rhetoric in his editions of juvenilia—the paradigm, drawn from Wordsworthʼs “Immotality Ode,” of childhood as a lost, divine state of being.

A survey of Shepherdʼs publications shows that he shared this essentialist, nostalgically sentimental view of the resources of childhood, despite also justifying his reprints of juvenilia with an organic, developmental view of the great writerʼs youth. In his editions of Blakeʼs Poetical Sketches (1868) and Songs of Innocence and of Experience (1866, 1868, 1874),Shepherdʼs publisher for the Blake editions, Basil Montagu , was the son of William, who published the first regular typographical edition of Blakeʼs Songs; the son restarted his fatherʼs publishing business in 1858 (Keynes, William , 35, 42). Shepherd assumes a view of juvenile literature similar to that in the Athenaeumʼs review of the the Lambsʼ Poetry for Children. He dotes on how the poems “will be cherished by children for their purity and simplicity, and by grown‐up men and women for the deeper meanings which always underlie the most simple of them:—‘Thoughts that do often lie too deep for tears.’ There is something sublime in the spirit of childlike innocence and Christian rebuke of worldliness and hardheartedness that pervades these productions. [Blake] sums up all the commandments under the precept, ‘Little children, love one another. For love is the fulfilling of the law. He that loveth not, knoweth not God; for God is love’” (Blake, Songs, ed. Shepherd, xi).

In one of Shepherdʼs own compositions, a presentation poem for a little girl, “To Florence at Haslemere, with Blakeʼs ‘Songs of Innocence,’” he invokes an essentialist view of English childhood, again like the Athenaeum reviewerʼs, of imaginative experience shaded in green lanes:

lg.l: Accept, dear child, these songs of one whose Muse
For happy children piped her sweetest lays,
Nor deemʼd their suffrages her lightest praise
Who hold Heavenʼs kingdom as their proper dues.
And wilt thou with the lyric gift refuse
His thanks, whose drooping spirits thou couldst raise
By airy gestures, graceful as a fayʼs
Dancing at eve in shady avenues?
With rapt delight I see you ponder long
The gentle words of one so pure of blame,
Who loved the right, who scornʼd and loathed the wrong

div.p: (Shepherd, Translations from Charles Baudelaire, with a Few Original Poems, 89)

Other poems by Shepherd on childhood concern childrenʼs reading and writing; another presentation to Florence, this time of Kingsleyʼs Water Babies; and valentine poems. One poem, “To W. T. Waite, with a Juvenile Poem,” was apparently written to accompany one of Shepherdʼs own juvenile poems, presented to the barrister who defended him in the trial contesting republication of the Barrett Browning juvenilia. The poem begins:

lg.l: Waite, while for loftier efforts I prepare,
Here with the first‐fruits unto thee I come,
And bring thee, chosen friend of childhood, some
Slight tribute to thy worth and goodness rare.

div.p: (Shepherd, Translations from Charles Baudelaire, with a Few Original Poems, 56)

Thus, Shepherd mildly presented himself as a modern author whose juvenilia merits regard. (Whether Waiteʼs status as a “chosen friend of childhood” refers to a shared boyhood with Shepherd himself, or to his championship of Shepherd as an editor of juvenilia, or both, is unknown.)For Waiteʼs cross‐examination of Robert Browning on behalf of Shepherd as plaintiff in “Shepherd v. Francis,” see Honan, “Browningʼs Testimony”.

Finally, the question most often raised about Shepherd, when he is mentioned at all in literary history, is whether to see him as a drunk and opportunistic hack or as a pioneering professional of nineteenth‐century bibliography. The question is not very relevant to our concerns in ERM, except to remark that the question, in how it is typically framed, misses a point crucial to understanding the context for publishing eminent authorsʼ juvenilia at the fin de siècle—namely, that the atmosphere in which editors and bibliographers like Shepherd worked was inherently ambiguous, the quality of the facsimile editions and “reprints” that they produced being disconcertingly staked on their close mimickry of the originals. W. D. Paden argues that Shepherdʼs reputation fell victim to that very ambiguity, in that Thomas J. Wise, who most masterfully exploited the murkiness of the book trade of the era, strategically set up Shepherd as a fall guy for the Wise/Forman forgeries should they come to require a decoy—as Wise did eventually use the conveniently deceased Shepherd, when need arose (Paden, “Tennysonʼs The Loverʼs Tale, Shepherd, and Wise,” 144–45). Carter and Sadleir incorporated Shepherd into their narratives of how disinterested modern bibliography arose from the intellectually compromised collecting of the late‐nineteenth century: Shepherd, not dishonorable in that development, as they see it, was an honest and industrious compiler of checklists (Carter, Taste and Technique in Book‐Collecting, 23; Sadleir, “Development of Bibliographical Study,” 149). Indeed, there is no evidence that Shepherd ever committed forgery; and works like his Tennysoniana, while scarcely profound, present a serious effort at criticism, reaching beyond biographical platitudes to examine subject matter, compare the poetic language of earlier and later works, point out patterns of revision, and research critical reception. At the same time, in his “reprints” he repeatedly and defiantly treaded close to piracy (see, e.g., Paden, “Tennysonʼs The Loverʼs Tale, Shepherd, and Wise,” 112–13, 119–20). Shepherdʼs career in the 1860s–80s reflects the shifting combinations of opportunism, exacting scholarship, and sentiment that contextualized W. G. Collingwoodʼs and George Allenʼs editing of Ruskinʼs juvenilia in the 1890s.
